description: Preposition and adverb from Middle English aboute, abouten, from Old English abūtan, onbūtan, from on (“in, on”) +‎ būtan (“outside of”), from be (“by”) +‎ ūtan (“outside”).

adjectives.description: Preposition and adverb from Middle English aboute, abouten, from Old English abūtan, onbūtan, from on (“in, on”) +‎ būtan (“outside of”), from be (“by”) +‎ ūtan (“outside”). Adjective from Middle English about (adverb).

entries.meaning: Moving around; astir.
examples: out and about;  up and about
After my bout with Guillan-Barre Syndrome, it took me 6 months to be up and about again.

entries.meaning: In existence; being in evidence; apparent.
examples: This idea has been about for a while but has only recently become fashionable.

entries.meaning: Near; in the vicinity or neighbourhood.
examples: I had my keys just a minute ago, so they must be about somewhere.
Watch out, there's a thief about.

entries.meaning: On all sides; around. [from before 1150]
examples: I looked about at the scenery that surrounded me.

entries.meaning: Here and there; around; in one place and another; up and down. [from before 1150]
examples: Bits of old machinery were lying about.

entries.meaning: From one place or position to another in succession; indicating repeated movement or activity.
examples: walking about;  rushing about;  jumping about;  thrashing about

entries.meaning: Indicating unproductive or unstructured activity.
examples: messing about;   fooling about;  loafing about

entries.meaning: Nearly; approximately; with close correspondence in quality, manner, degree, quantity, or time; almost. [from before 1150]
examples: It's about as cold as it was last winter.
He owes me about three hundred dollars.
Dinner's about ready.
I was so scared, I about fainted.

entries.meaning: Near; in the vicinity. [from ca. 1350–1470]

definitionGroups.group: To a reversed order; half round; facing in the opposite direction; from a contrary point of view. [from ca. 1350–1470]

entries.meaning: (nautical) To the opposite tack: see go about. [from late 15th c.]
examples: We went about and headed offshore.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or rare) In succession; one after another; in the course of events. [from before 1150]
examples: When he had finished, he drew his plaid around his head, and went slowly down to the little dell, where he used every day to offer up his morning and evening prayers, and where we have often sat together on Sabbath afternoons, reading verse about with our children in the Bible.

entries.meaning: (archaic) In circuit; circularly; by a circuitous way; around the outside; in circumference. [from ca. 1350–1470]
examples: a mile about, and a third of a mile across

prepositions.description: Preposition and adverb from Middle English aboute, abouten, from Old English abūtan, onbūtan, from on (“in, on”) +‎ būtan (“outside of”), from be (“by”) +‎ ūtan (“outside”). Adjective from Middle English about (adverb).

entries.meaning: In a circle around; all round; on every side of; on the outside of. [from before 1150]
examples: The snake was coiled about his ankle.

entries.meaning: Over or upon different parts of; through or over in various directions; here and there in; to and fro in; throughout. [from ca. 1150–1350]
examples: Rubbish was strewn about the place.
The children were running about the room.
He was well known about town.

definitionGroups.group: Indicates that something will happen very soon; indicates a plan or intention to do something.

entries.meaning: (with 'to' and verb infinitive) See about to.
(with present participle, obsolete or dialect) On the point or verge of.
examples: [It] was held, that the latter requirement was fulfilled by an affidavit declaring that "the defendant was about leaving the State permanently."

entries.meaning: Concerning; with regard to; on account of; on the subject of; to affect. [from ca. 1150–1350]
examples: He talked a lot about his childhood.
We must do something about this problem.

entries.meaning: Concerned with; engaged in; intent on. [from ca. 1150–1350]
examples: to be about one's business

entries.meaning: Within or in the immediate neighborhood of; in contiguity or proximity to; near, as to place. [from ca. 1350–1470]
examples: I can't find my reading glasses, but they must be somewhere about the house.
John's in the garden, probably somewhere about the woodshed.

entries.meaning: On one's person; nearby the person. [from ca. 1350–1470]
examples: I had no weapon about me but a stick.

entries.meaning: (figurative) In or near, as in mental faculties or (literally) in the possession of; under the control of; at one's command; in one's makeup. [from ca. 1350–1470]
examples: He has his wits about him.
There was an air of confidence about the woman.
